translated: Jātaka
Dvādasakanipāta
Cūḷakuṇālavagga
Janasandhajātaka
“Ten these are the ten things,
Which if one does not do before,
One will regret later on,
So says the wise Janasandha.

analyzed: a laddhā vittam tappati  pubbe a samudānita
translated: One regrets not having acquired wealth
Which one did not acquire before,🔽Thinking: ‘I will not get wealth later on,’

analyzed: iti pacchā anutappati  sakya rūpam pure santa
translated: One regrets it later on.🔽Thinking: ‘I did not learn a craft
When I was young and able,’
One regrets it later on,
For it is hard to live without a craft.

analyzed: kūṭavedī pure āsi  pisuṇaḥ piṭṭhi masiko
translated: Thinking: ‘I was a slanderer before,🔽A backbiter and a tale-bearer,
Harsh and irritable,’
One regrets it later on.

analyzed: pāṇa atipātī pure āsi  luddaḥ ca api anāriyaḥ
translated: Thinking: ‘I was a killer of living beings before,🔽A hunter, not a noble person,
And did not respect living beings,’
One regrets it later on.
Thinking: ‘There were many women
Who were not taken by others,🔽And I did not take another’s wife,’

analyzed: iti pacchā anutappati  bahumhi vata santamhi
translated: One regrets it later on.🔽Thinking: ‘There was much food and drink
Which was given to me,
And I did not give a gift before,’
One regrets it later on.
Thinking: ‘I did not support my mother and father
Old age has come, youth has passed,
I have not saved anything,
thus later he suffers remorse.
The teacher, the preceptor,
the one who brings all sensual pleasures,
my father I have disrespected,
thus later he suffers remorse.
The ascetics and the brahmins,
the virtuous ones, the learned ones,
I have not previously served,

analyzed: iti pacchā anutappati  sādhu hoti tapaḥ ciṇṇaḥ
translated: thus later he suffers remorse.🔽It is good to have practiced austerities,
and to have served the virtuous ones,
but I have not previously practiced austerities,
thus later he suffers remorse.🔽But he who practices properly

analyzed: yaḥ ca etāni ṭhānāni  yonisaḥ paṭipajjati
translated: in these matters,
doing his duties as a man,
later he does not suffer remorse.”
The Birth Story of Janasandha, the Fifth.
